title: Elon Musk's 4-year-old son X spotted at Senate. The reason is...
content: Ahead of Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's meeting with the Senate and House Republicans Thursday, Elon Musk met incoming Senate Majority Leader John Thune. ​“I think we just need to make sure we spend the public’s money well," Elon Musk said as he came out of the meeting holding the hand of his four-year-old whom he took to the Senate.
summary: Ahead of Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's meeting with the Senate and House Republicans Thursday, Elon Musk met incoming Senate Majority Leader John Thune. ​“I think we just need to make sure we spend the public’s money well," Elon Musk said as he came out of the meeting holding the hand of his four-year-old whom he took to the Senate.

title: Escalating Syria conflict is a 'chronic collective failure': UN chief

Poland gets $4 billion US loan for defence purchases, minister says
content: Poland secured a $4 billion loan from the US foreign military financing program to bolster its armed forces. This adds to over $11 billion in US support for Polish armament programs, including Patriot and Apache systems. Driven by the war in Ukraine, Poland's 2024 defense spending will reach 4.1% of GDP, rising to 4.7% in 2025.
summary: Poland secured a $4 billion loan from the US foreign military financing program to bolster its armed forces.  This adds to over $11 billion in US support for Polish armament programs, including Patriot and Apache systems.  Driven by the war in Ukraine, Poland's 2024 defense spending will reach 4.1% of GDP, rising to 4.7% in 2025.

title: Killer of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson seen grinning in new photos
content: The NYPD released photos gunman who fatally shot UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson outside a Midtown Hilton. The photos, taken from a youth hostel, show the killer's face for the first time. No person has yet been nabbed in connection with the killing though bizarre clues have been found. The shell casings had words 'deny', 'defend', 'depose' written on them.
summary: The NYPD released photos gunman who fatally shot UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson outside a Midtown Hilton.  The photos, taken from a youth hostel, show the killer's face for the first time. No person has yet been nabbed in connection with the killing though bizarre clues have been found. The shell casings had words 'deny', 'defend', 'depose' written on them.

title: Work-life balance isn't working for women. Why?
content: Working women are experiencing record levels of stress due to competing work and family demands, a new Gallup report reveals. Many are declining promotions or considering leaving their jobs due to childcare issues, exacerbated by high costs and lack of support. However, employers can improve well-being and retain talent by prioritizing work-life balance and providing support systems.
summary: Working women are experiencing record levels of stress due to competing work and family demands, a new Gallup report reveals.  Many are declining promotions or considering leaving their jobs due to childcare issues, exacerbated by high costs and lack of support.  However, employers can improve well-being and retain talent by prioritizing work-life balance and providing support systems.

title: Bangladesh to drop Sheikh Mujibur Rahman’s image from currency notes amid political overhaul: Report
content: Following the ouster of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh is redesigning its currency. The image of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, Hasina's father and the nation's founding leader, will be replaced with symbols of the July uprising that led to Hasina's removal. This move is part of a broader reshaping of national identity under the interim government.
summary: Following the ouster of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh is redesigning its currency. The image of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, Hasina's father and the nation's founding leader, will be replaced with symbols of the July uprising that led to Hasina's removal. This move is part of a broader reshaping of national identity under the interim government.

title: Who is 35-year-old Ahn Gwi-ryeong who grabbed soldier's gun after South Korea martial law order?
content: As many social media posts praised Ahen Gwi-ryeong's bravery, one particular claimed that she is a descendant of Ahn Juhn-geun who assassinated Ito Hirobumi in 1909. "The spokesperson of Democratic Party bravely confronting martial law forces fully armed with firearms. She’s Ahn Gwi-ryeong and descended from Ahn Jung-geun who assassinated Ito Hirobumi at Harbin 1909. Protecting the country against tyranny is her family occupation," the post said.
summary: As many social media posts praised Ahen Gwi-ryeong's bravery, one particular claimed that she is a descendant of Ahn Juhn-geun who assassinated Ito Hirobumi in 1909. "The spokesperson of Democratic Party bravely confronting martial law forces fully armed with firearms. She’s Ahn Gwi-ryeong and descended from Ahn Jung-geun who assassinated Ito Hirobumi at Harbin 1909. Protecting the country against tyranny is her family occupation," the post said.

title: Anatomy of a Murder: The chilling assassination of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson
content: The targeted killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson has gripped the nation, highlighting tensions surrounding the US healthcare system. The assailant, clad in tactical gear, executed the attack near a hotel before fleeing on an e-bike. Evidence suggests a grievance-driven motive, with cryptic messages like "delay" and "depose" etched on shell casings, possibly referencing denied insurance claims. Thompson’s role in a criticized for-profit healthcare system and the industry's alleged abuses have sparked polarized reactions. Public discourse reflects anger over systemic inequities, raising broader questions about corporate accountability, healthcare reform, and the potential normalization of violence in addressing societal grievances.
summary: The targeted killing of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson has gripped the nation, highlighting tensions surrounding the US healthcare system. The assailant, clad in tactical gear, executed the attack near a hotel before fleeing on an e-bike. Evidence suggests a grievance-driven motive, with cryptic messages like "delay" and "depose" etched on shell casings, possibly referencing denied insurance claims. Thompson’s role in a criticized for-profit healthcare system and the industry's alleged abuses have sparked polarized reactions. Public discourse reflects anger over systemic inequities, raising broader questions about corporate accountability, healthcare reform, and the potential normalization of violence in addressing societal grievances.

title: Trump's America? University of Michigan drops DEI hiring
content: The university’s relationship with DEI initiatives has been both longstanding and complex. In 2016, the institution launched DEI 1.0, its inaugural five-year strategic plan designed to weave principles of diversity, equity, and inclusion into the fabric of campus life. This initiative sought to create a more inclusive environment and address systemic inequities. Following a period of review, the university introduced DEI 2.0 in October 2023, emphasizing goals such as affordability, access, and a renewed commitment to fostering an inclusive community. This broader framework remains firmly in place, even as the university reevaluates specific policies like the DEI statement requirement.
summary: The university’s relationship with DEI initiatives has been both longstanding and complex. In 2016, the institution launched DEI 1.0, its inaugural five-year strategic plan designed to weave principles of diversity, equity, and inclusion into the fabric of campus life. This initiative sought to create a more inclusive environment and address systemic inequities. Following a period of review, the university introduced DEI 2.0 in October 2023, emphasizing goals such as affordability, access, and a renewed commitment to fostering an inclusive community. This broader framework remains firmly in place, even as the university reevaluates specific policies like the DEI statement requirement.

title: Democrat Ro Khanna says he wants to work with Musk, Vivek Ramaswamy's DOGE, Elon reacts
content: Congressman Ro Khanna offered to collaborate with Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's Department of Government Efficiency to reduce government waste. The statement came as Musk and Ramaswamy are scheduled to visit Capitol Hill today to meet with Republican lawmakers in both chambers of Congress to discuss what DOGE is set out to achieve.
summary: Congressman Ro Khanna offered to collaborate with Elon Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy's Department of Government Efficiency to reduce government waste.  The statement came as Musk and Ramaswamy are scheduled to visit Capitol Hill today to meet with Republican lawmakers in both chambers of Congress to discuss what DOGE is set out to achieve.

title: France PM Michel Barnier resigns after no confidence motion, to stay in office till new government named
content: French Prime Minister Michel Barnier resigned after a historic no-confidence vote ousted his government. This marks the first successful such vote since 1962. President Macron faces pressure to quickly appoint a successor amid a hung parliament and political instability. Barnier's controversial budget proposal triggered the crisis, leaving France without an approved budget.
summary: French Prime Minister Michel Barnier resigned after a historic no-confidence vote ousted his government. This marks the first successful such vote since 1962. President Macron faces pressure to quickly appoint a successor amid a hung parliament and political instability. Barnier's controversial budget proposal triggered the crisis, leaving France without an approved budget.

title: 'Poetic Justice': Why some Americans are celebrating UnitedHealthcare CEO’s murder
content: The shocking murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson has sparked polarised reactions, highlighting the deep frustration many Americans feel toward the US healthcare system. Thompson’s leadership symbolised a profit-driven industry criticised for denying care and financial exploitation. Social media flooded with dark humour and anger, with some viewing his death as karmic justice. Journalist Taylor Lorenz's meme further fuelled controversy, reflecting the public’s disdain for systemic inequities. While critics warn against normalising violence, the incident underscores a growing demand for universal healthcare and reform. Thompson’s death serves as a grim symbol of a healthcare system many believe is irreparably broken.
summary: The shocking murder of UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson has sparked polarised reactions, highlighting the deep frustration many Americans feel toward the US healthcare system. Thompson’s leadership symbolised a profit-driven industry criticised for denying care and financial exploitation. Social media flooded with dark humour and anger, with some viewing his death as karmic justice. While critics warn against normalising violence, the incident underscores a growing demand for universal healthcare and reform. Thompson’s death serves as a grim symbol of a healthcare system many believe is irreparably broken.

title: Does Donald Trump have an IQ of 73? What is the truth behind this viral claim?
content: How much is Donald Trump's IQ? The answer is not known as he never released his IQ score though he took jibes at Joe Biden and Kamala Harris and all other opponents by calling them low-IQ persons. In 2019, the claim that Donald Trump's IQ is 73 went viral. The same clip resurfaced on X Thursday making the same claim. An IQ of 73 indicated mental retardation.
summary: How much is Donald Trump's IQ? The answer is not known as he never released his IQ score though he took jibes at Joe Biden and Kamala Harris and all other opponents by calling them low-IQ persons. In 2019, the claim that Donald Trump's IQ is 73 went viral. The same clip resurfaced on X Thursday making the same claim. An IQ of 73 indicated mental retardation.

title: China sanctions 13 US military firms over Taiwan arms sales​​
content: China imposed sanctions on 13 US military companies and six executives following US arms sales to Taiwan and President Lai Ching-te's US transit. Beijing views the $385 million arms deal, including F-16 support, as a threat to its sovereignty and opposes Taiwan's leader's foreign interactions, considering Taiwan its territory.
summary: China imposed sanctions on 13 US military companies and six executives following US arms sales to Taiwan and President Lai Ching-te's US transit.  Beijing views the $385 million arms deal, including F-16 support, as a threat to its sovereignty and opposes Taiwan's leader's foreign interactions, considering Taiwan its territory.

title: Viral post decodes 'deny, depose...' message on bullets that killed UnitedHealthcare CEO
content: ​ A post has now claimed to have decoded the encrypted message and divulged the eerie link between the three words and the title of a book by Jay M Feinman 'Delay Deny Defend'. The book is about insurance companies which drag their feet on paying the claims and UnitedHealthcare is an insurance company. "Why insurance companies don't pay claims and what you can do about it," the description of the book reads.
summary: ​ A post has now claimed to have decoded the encrypted message and divulged the eerie link between the three words and the title of a book by Jay M Feinman 'Delay Deny Defend'. The book is about insurance companies which drag their feet on paying the claims and UnitedHealthcare is an insurance company. "Why insurance companies don't pay claims and what you can do about it," the description of the book reads.

title: Pete Hegseth comes clean on drinking problem allegations: 'What do guys do when...'
content: Pete Hegseth said he like all normal guys have had a glass of beer or two but he never had a stinking problem. He never had to be counseled for that either. But you know, what do guys do when they come back from war oftentimes? Have some beers. How do you deal with the demons you see on the battlefield? Sometimes it's with a bottle."
summary: Pete Hegseth said he like all normal guys have had a glass of beer or two but he never had a stinking problem. He never had to be counseled for that either. But you know, what do guys do when they come back from war oftentimes? Have some beers. How do you deal with the demons you see on the battlefield? Sometimes it's with a bottle."

title: Did UnitedHealthcare CEO Brian Thompson's killer leave a clue in nearby Starbucks?
content: The killer made a stop at the nearby Starbucks just before the killing and bought a coffee, a water bottle and two power bars from the store. In the surveillance footage, he was seen tossing the coffee cup and the water bottle in the trash can. the NYPD investigators are decoding if the killer left some vital clues apart from the "deny", "depose", and "defend" engraved in the shell casings.
summary: The killer made a stop at the nearby Starbucks just before the killing and bought a coffee, a water bottle and two power bars from the store. In the surveillance footage, he was seen tossing the coffee cup and the water bottle in the trash can. the NYPD investigators are decoding if the killer left some vital clues apart from the "deny", "depose", and "defend" engraved in the shell casings.

title: 'My ears are bleeding': Why SC Justice Ketanji Jackson comparing gender surgery for minors to interracial marriage is sparking fury
content: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson compared bans on gender-affirming care to interracial marriage prohibitions during a Supreme Court hearing, sparking debate. Critics argue her analogy conflates distinct legal issues, as Loving v. Virginia addressed racial discrimination under strict scrutiny, while gender-affirming care involves medical and ethical complexities, subject to differing standards of review. The comparison also highlights disparities in public acceptance; interracial marriage is widely supported, while gender-affirming care remains contentious. Some view Jackson's remarks as judicial activism, framing the issue as a civil rights imperative. The debate underscores tensions between state authority, evolving public opinion, and courts' role in safeguarding equality.
summary: Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson compared bans on gender-affirming care to interracial marriage prohibitions during a Supreme Court hearing, sparking debate. Critics argue her analogy conflates distinct legal issues, as Loving v. Virginia addressed racial discrimination under strict scrutiny, while gender-affirming care involves medical and ethical complexities, subject to differing standards of review. The comparison also highlights disparities in public acceptance; interracial marriage is widely supported, while gender-affirming care remains contentious. Some view Jackson's remarks as judicial activism, framing the issue as a civil rights imperative. The debate underscores tensions between state authority, evolving public opinion, and courts' role in safeguarding equality.
